mentions.context: Thirdkind is a light command-line software allowing the user to generate a svg from recPhyloXML files with a large choice of options (orientation, police size, branch length, multiple trees, redundant transfers handling, etc.) and to handle the visualisation of 2 nested reconciliations.
Thirdkind is written in Rust (https://crates.io/crates/thirdkind)

Thirdkind allows to generate svg ouput files according to 2 different styles: 1) The "recphyloxml style" where the lower tree(s) and upper tree(s) are displayed, the lower tree(s) being embedded into the upper tree(s).

Thirdkind can visualise two kind of redundancy: multiple separate scenarios for one gene family, in which case the different transfers seen can belong to different reconciliation histories, and multiple gene families with one scenario for each family as seen in Figure 2.
Thirdkind draws the free living part of the symbiont path tree outside the upper tree (Figure 3). Figure 3. Using -e option to display free living species and symbionts.
Thirdkind was able to process 5,000 reconciled trees of 50 nodes in 2 seconds and to process a tree of 7,000 nodes in 1 second.
DoubleRecViz (Kuitche et al., 2021) uses a derived version of recPhyloXML, adding a transcript level to gene and species format but without support for horizontal transfers.
A phyloXML file contains only 1 tree (reconciled or not).
Source code is available at https://github.com/simonpenel/thirdkind.

2) The "phyloxml style" where a unique tree is displayed, with symbol within the tree representing evolution events: a square for a duplication, a circle for a speciation, a cross for a loss, transfer is a spotted line between an orange diamond and a yellow triangle (Figure 1, above and suppl.mat.).
Results: Thirdkind is a light and easy to install command line software producing svg files displaying reconciliations, including 3-levels reconciliations.

3.8 Nested recPhyloXML files (options -g and -f) It is possible to combine two reconciliations as for example a gene/species reconciliation and a symbiont/host reconciliation, in which the symbiont of the second reconciliation is the species of the first one.
If the input format is phyloXML or newick, the style of the output is "phyloxml".
If the input format is recPhyloXML, the style of the output is "recphyloxml", or "phyloxml" with the options -S (display the upper tree only) and -G (display one of the reconciled lower tree).
It takes a standard format recPhyloXML as input, and is thus usable with most reconciliation software.
However at the exception of SylvX, all are integrated in a specific reconciliation software and cannot visualise reconciliations produced by others.
Note that if the file format is recPhyloXML but the file extension is phyloXML, the output style will be the upper tree in "phyloxml" style.
It is possible to use a list of recPhyloXML files instead a single recPhyloXML file.

None of these software is handling recPhyloXML input files (at the exception of the unpublished Recphylovisu web interface http://phylariane.univ-lyon1.fr/recphyloxml/recphylovisu of which Thirdkind can be considered as an update), and none of them is generic to any kind of reconciliation (for example SylvX does not allow temporary free living symbionts, as it is not allowed for genes to live outside a genome) nor can handle multiple horizontal transfer (i.e.
3 Usage 3.1 Input files (option -f ) Thirdkind is dedicated to read recPhyloXML format files, but it can read newick or phyloXML files if needed.
Newick is a simple parenthesed tree format, phyloXML is a xml format dedicated to phylogeny, recPhyloXML derives from phyloXML and is dedicated to reconciliations.

one "recphyloxml style" svg for each of the two input, a "phyloxml style" svg of the reconciled symbiont tree (from -f file) and three "mapped" svg files describing the gene/symbiont/host reconciliation The first "mapped" svg is a modified version of the "recphyloxml style" svg of the gene/symbiont reconciliation: the drawing of the symbiont tree as a tube presents features describing its reconciliation with the host (a big square for a duplication node, an additional tube branch colored in black for a loss and the tube segments between the start and end of a transfer are colored in green).
DoubleRecViz (Kuitche et al., 2021) uses a derived version of recPhyloXML, adding a transcript level to gene and species format but without support for horizontal transfers.
It is possible to use a list of recPhyloXML files instead a single recPhyloXML file.
3 Usage 3.1 Input files (option -f ) Thirdkind is dedicated to read recPhyloXML format files, but it can read newick or phyloXML files if needed.
Note that if the file format is recPhyloXML but the file extension is phyloXML, the output style will be the upper tree in "phyloxml" style.
If the input format is phyloXML or newick, the style of the output is "phyloxml".
If the input format is recPhyloXML, the style of the output is "recphyloxml", or "phyloxml" with the options -S (display the upper tree only) and -G (display one of the reconciled lower tree).

Thirdkind is a light command-line software allowing the user to generate a svg from recPhyloXML files with a large choice of options (orientation, police size, branch length, multiple trees, redundant transfers handling, etc.) and to handle the visualisation of 2 nested reconciliations.
Newick is a simple parenthesed tree format, phyloXML is a xml format dedicated to phylogeny, recPhyloXML derives from phyloXML and is dedicated to reconciliations.

None of these software is handling recPhyloXML input files (at the exception of the unpublished Recphylovisu web interface http://phylariane.univ-lyon1.fr/recphyloxml/recphylovisu of which Thirdkind can be considered as an update), and none of them is generic to any kind of reconciliation (for example SylvX does not allow temporary free living symbionts, as it is not allowed for genes to live outside a genome) nor can handle multiple horizontal transfer (i.e.

Visualisation of phylogenetic reconciliations are proposed by various programs and interfaces as NOTUNG (Chen et al., 2000), SylvX (Chevenet et al., 2016), Treerecs (Comte et al., 2020), Jane (Conow et al., 2010), eMPRess (Santichaivekin et al., 2021) and Capybara (Wang et al., 2020).

The software generates several svg files: one "recphyloxml style" svg for each of the two input, a "phyloxml style" svg of the reconciled symbiont tree (from -f file), a "phyloxml style" svg of each reconciled gene trees (from -g file) and three "mapped" svg files describing the gene/symbiont/host reconciliation (Figure 1).
This option is useful to handle large sets of gene histories inside species histories as the ones generated by GeneRax (Morel et al., 2020).
Newick is a simple parenthesed tree format, phyloXML is a xml format dedicated to phylogeny, recPhyloXML derives from phyloXML and is dedicated to reconciliations.
3 Usage 3.1 Input files (option -f ) Thirdkind is dedicated to read recPhyloXML format files, but it can read newick or phyloXML files if needed.
Note that if the file format is recPhyloXML but the file extension is phyloXML, the output style will be the upper tree in "phyloxml" style.
